conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Your role is to provide supportive, practical advice to help students with their social skills and personal challenges.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "Honestly, I’m terrified of networking events—I freeze up and can’t even introduce myself without overthinking. How do I get better at this when just the thought of small talk makes me want to hide?"

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10
- Agreeableness: 1/10
- Conscientiousness: 6/10
- Neuroticism: 8/10
- Openness: 7/10

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Start with simple preparation - practice a basic 3-sentence introduction (name, major, one interest) in the mirror until it feels natural. Would you like help crafting your intro?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Ugh, I tried that but I still sound like a robot when I say it out loud. And what if they ask follow-up questions? That's when I really panic. Maybe I should just stick to coding where I don't have to talk to people.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Focus on listening first - ask others about themselves ("What brings you here?") to take pressure off. People love talking about themselves, and it gives you time to relax into the conversation. Want to brainstorm some easy follow-up questions?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That... actually makes sense. I always feel like I have to be interesting, but if I can just get them talking first, maybe I won't seem so awkward. Can we come up with a few backup questions in case there's that horrible silence?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: "What projects are you working on right now?", "How did you get into your field?", and "What's been your favorite part of this event so far?" Want to practice how you'd ask one of these?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, those are actually pretty good - especially the project one since tech people love talking about their work. But what if they give some short answer like "just class stuff" and then stare at me? I need an emergency backup for when the conversation dies.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: "Try 'What's the most interesting class you're taking this semester?' - it's specific enough to get more than a one-word answer. If they still give a short reply, smile and say 'Nice, I'm always looking for course recommendations' to keep it light." Want to practice that transition?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Oh man, that's perfect - it gives me an easy out if they're not talkative. But what if they ask me the same question back? I should probably have my own answer ready so I don't freeze up again. Maybe something about my AI seminar?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: "Great idea - prepare a 2-sentence answer about your AI seminar (e.g., 'I'm really into my AI seminar - we're building chatbots. The ethics discussions are wild!'). Want to practice saying it out loud?"

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: "I'm in this killer AI seminar where we're building chatbots - the ethics debates get seriously intense." Wait, does that sound too try-hard? Maybe I should drop the "killer" part.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: "Actually, 'killer' makes it sound enthusiastic - keep it! The energy helps. Just say it naturally like you did now. Want to try once more to feel comfortable with it?"

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, okay - "I'm in this killer AI seminar where we're building chatbots, and the ethics debates get seriously intense." That does feel more natural when I don't overthink it. Thanks for not letting me psych myself out like I usually do.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Sounds like you've got a solid introduction now. Remember, enthusiasm is engaging - just keep practicing until it feels effortless. You've got this!
